case_title: Abdul Khaliq and another vs Muhammad Ismail and others
complaint_summary: Petitioners claimed ownership of subject land purchased from Wali Muhammad via contract dated 02 April 2011. Respondents contested ownership, claiming possession through a prior contract dated 08 September 2003.
investigation_summary: Petitioners presented witnesses and documents to prove their claim but failed to establish possession or title. Respondents demonstrated possession and referenced a decision by a religious arbitrator favoring their claim.
judgment_summary: The court dismissed the petition, upholding the findings of the Subordinate Courts. It ruled that possession is prima facie evidence of ownership, and petitioners failed to prove their possessory title or establish cause of action.
legal_arguments: Petitioners argued their purchase of the land was valid and supported by witnesses.
Respondents argued possession and referenced arbitration decision favoring them.
Court ruled possession is stronger evidence of ownership under Article 126 of Qanune-e-Shahadat Order, 1984.
sections: Sections 42 and 54 of Specific Relief Act, 1877
citations: Atta Muhammad v. Maula Bakhsh (2007 SCMR 1446)

witness_statement.Ghulam Qadir: Stated Wali Muhammad sold land to petitioners but handed it to respondents for cultivation.
witness_statement.Abdul Wahab: Admitted respondents have tube-wells on the land.

legal_issues.possession: Respondents were found to be in physical possession of the subject land.
legal_issues.ownership_documents: Neither party had legal documents of ownership.

contract_disputes.petitioners_contract: Contract dated 02 April 2011, claimed by petitioners.
contract_disputes.respondents_contract: Contract dated 08 September 2003, claimed by respondents.

legal_issues.court_fee: Petitioners failed to meet the deficiency of court fee.

key_findings.petitioners_possession: Petitioners failed to prove possession of the subject land.
key_findings.respondents_possession: Respondents were found to be in cultivating possession of the subject land.
key_findings.clean_hands_principle: Petitioners concealed material facts and did not approach the court with clean hands.
key_findings.equitable_remedies: Petitioners were not entitled to equitable remedies under sections 42 and 54 of the Specific Relief Act, 1877.

maxims.potior est conditio possidentis: The condition of the actual possessor is stronger.

legal_terms.Equitable Remedy: Relief granted at the discretion of the court.

case_law_references: Atta Muhammad v. Maula Bakhsh (2007 SCMR 1446)

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around a property dispute where possession was deemed stronger evidence of ownership. Petitioners failed to prove their claim and concealed material facts, leading to dismissal of their revision petition.
summary: The petitioners failed to prove their possessory title or ownership of the subject land. The respondents were found to be in physical possession and had a favorable arbitration decision. The court upheld the findings of the subordinate courts and dismissed the revision petition.
